narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Laurene Petitjean  Laurene.
Instructor: Laurene Petitjean  Laurene

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Laurene Petitjean  Laurene was an excellent teaching assistant. She was always available to answer questions. I attended many of her office hour sessions and she was always willing to explain the concept over and over again until I understood it. However, there were two other "teaching fellows" that supported the class as well. I felt that the teaching team was not proportional to the size of the class. On average there were about 15 people in the class. For this size there was a professor and three teaching fellows. When there are that many people "responsible" for the class - the responsibilities are diffused. I am sure (and well aware) that it is difficult to structure a class like this, however, for the amount of "teachers" there was still a large disconnect between them, the material, and us.
Instructor: Laurene Petitjean  She was great but having the other 2 TFs caused confusion as they weren't as organized or clear.
Instructor: Laurene Petitjean  Easily accessible by email, answered questions clearly

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I am very interested in this subject and wanted to take this class to gain a better appreciation for green chemistry. I understand that it is very difficult to teach a green chemistry class to undergraduate and graduate students with a varying level of chemistry and environmental backgrounds. This class is very valuable to all students remotely interested in pursuing this field. However, some combination of factors made this course difficult to enjoy. First, the teaching team was too large and not proportional to the number of students, making it slightly disorganized and unrealistic (it is somewhere between a flipped and not flipped class). Second, for people who have not had chemistry in a few years, the introduction part of this course assumes you have some familiarity with the subject. Third, you don't have regular assignments which makes it difficult to test (and demonstrate) your understanding throughout the course, besides a midterm. Lastly, even with so many "teachers" I felt like they still did not have a handle on whether and if people were not on the same page with the material.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: some of the videos were helpful in giving you a basic background of topics but usually they were too boring or too short to get anything great out of them
interesting topics and case studies, discussion was good, tried to get students to engage with material

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Organization. The teaching team tried to pack too much into each lecture. First, you had to watch videos + read ahead of time (like a flipped class), then there would be a lecture, and sometimes a group activity -- which we would never be able to finish or make the most out of because we would run out of time. Clarity. For the basic chemistry part of the class, the practice work was not indicative of the actual content that we were expected to know. We were given packets of examples that were full of errors and "cross out because you don't kneed to know this" etc.

i wish we used more case studies and didn't just talk about the issues with recycling or sustainability. there could have been assigned background info for non ES students and we could've focused on the real nuts and bolts in class.

Class seemed disorganized at times, the chemistry section of the course was taught too quickly,lost a lot of people in the beginning of the class, even with TA help, The entire semester was needed to work on the final project because it was very detailed and should not have been left to the second half of the semester, the structure of the class was very demanding at times - assignments and homework and project

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: gain better understanding of the subject material as it would apply to my future job
I thought it would be interesting to learn about

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I wanted to refresh some chemistry and learn about green chemistry and I was able to do both.
i feel as though i learned a little but wished i learn more about chemistry via case studies
No, the course did cover very good topics, but it seemed too chemistry based in the beginning and then not tangible at the end
Not at all.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The course backs into the group project. Would have preferred an individual project - it was a tiny class and several project opportunities - no client involved.
advantages- dive deep on a topic
Team working helps reduce work load but is way less efficient than working alone.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you are interested in green chemistry, take it! However, you should be warned that this class has a lot of structural issues - too many teachers, the class is mixed with people with different chemistry backgrounds, and is somewhere between a flipped and non-flipped class.
decent course, but very undergrad-like with "attendance" and such. the attendance was pointless and felt unprofessional.
Have a strong chemistry background and shop the class first
I don't recommend this course.
